page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY GOG MAGOGS
page.content: Historically, the area was important from the 1 Century BC as an Iron Age hill fort, defended by the Catavellauni, as it overlooked the river valleys that joined just south of Cambridge. For East Anglians journeying from Colchester to the Midlands and the North, the Romans built a road past Wandlebury over the Gog Magog hills and crossing the Granta valley. During the Napoleonic Wars the height of the land was again important. A telegraph system using nine shutters was used to signal messages between Newmarket to the North and Therfield Heath in the South. Thus a message could be sent from Great Yarmouth to London in under 3/4 hour. Today MAGPAS uses an aerial erected on Hill Top Farm.
